text:
Centre Street, east side, north from Pearl Street. Buildings shown across the background, are on the north side of Leonard Street, east from Centre to Baxter Streets. The 1-story building in the foreground, is used by the Child Welfare Board, and is on the north side of Worth Street, east of Centre Street. Eventually this will form the site of the N.Y. State Office Building.

September 24, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

SLIDE # 241, 248.

Centre Street, east side, at Pearl Street, showing work in progress for the Federal Courts Building.
June 22, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Centre Street, east side, from and including Pearl, to and including Duane Streets, as seen from Lafayette Street, showing the Federal Courts Building in process of construction.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date

June 5, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Centre Street, east side, from and including Pearl, to and including Duane Streets, as seen from Lafayette Street, showing the Federal Courts Building in process of construction.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date

June 5, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

Centre Street (right), north from but not including Pearl Street, showing (center of view) prominently the Building for the Department of Health, Hospitals and Sanitation on the north side of Worth Street, between Centre and Lafayette (left) Streets.  Also shown (right) is part of the New York State Office Building, on the east side of Centre Street, north from Worth to Leonard Streets.  The area appearing the foreground is known as Foley Square.

April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, a closer view, and showing a small part on the west side of Centre Street, north from Pearl to Worth Streets; a part of the Square.
April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(3)

The same, a more limited view.

April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

Foley Square: The New York County Court House on the east side of Centre Street, between Pearl and Worth Streets, as viewed northward from the steps of the Federal Courts Bldg. At the extreme left appears a portion of the New York State Bldg.

June 12, 1938.

P. L. Sperr
